profileText: A Representative from Ohio; born in Hollis, Hillsborough County, N.H., August 30, 1804; attended the common schools and was graduated from Harvard University in 1830; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1835 and began practice in Norwalk, Huron County, Ohio; member of the State senate in 1849 and 1850; served as judge of the court of common pleas in 1859 and 1860; elected as a Republican to the Thirty-seventh Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of John Sherman and served from July 4, 1861, to March 3, 1863; resumed the practice of law and engaged in literary pursuits; died in Nashua, N.H., on December 6, 1882; interment in the South Cemetery, Hollis, N.H.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by the resignation of John Sherman, and took his seat July 4, 1861.

researchRecord.name: In the Joseph E. Worcester Papers, 1784-1865, 4 boxes and 3 cased volumes.
In the Benjamin Franklin Prescott Papers, 1879-1885, 4 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Samuel T. Worcester.

researchRecord.name: 1861, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from an unidentified individual to Samuel T. Worcester written on December 12, 1861. The unidentified individual refers to the nomination of a candidate to the Naval Academy.
